stem: The intensive care nurse is analyzing arterial blood gas (ABG) results for three clients with multiple comorbidities. Based on the documentation in the Complex Laboratory Flowsheet, match each lab profile to its correct pathological driver.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 65-year-old male with COPD (chronic CO2 retainer) currently in AKI.
Patient B: 28-year-old female with DKA (metabolic acidosis) who was just given a high-dose sedative (respiratory depression).
Patient C: 50-year-old male with chronic vomiting (metabolic alkalosis) following a panic attack (hyperventilation).

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
Patient B: BP 88/54, HR 132, RR 10 (shallow).
Patient C: BP 110/68, HR 118, RR 42 (rapid).

rows.text: pH 7.18, High PaCO2, Low HCO3- (Double Acidosis)
pH 7.58, Low PaCO2, High HCO3- (Double Alkalosis)
pH 7.28, High PaCO2, Low HCO3- (Mixed Resp/Met Acidosis)

rationale.correct: Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis (c1) occurs when the lungs cannot breathe effectively (high PaCO2) AND the kidneys/body cells are failing (low HCO3-), as seen in r1 and r3. The pH drops dangerously low because NO compensation is possible. Mixed respiratory and metabolic alkalosis (c2) occurs when the lungs are hyperventilating (low PaCO2) AND the body is losing acid (high HCO3-), as seen in r2.
clinicalPearls: Mixed acid-base imbalances are the most dangerous because the body has no system left to compensate.
In mixed acidosis, the pH will be significantly lower than in a simple imbalance.
Check the 'drivers': If BOTH PaCO2 and HCO3- are moving in the 'wrong' direction for the pH, it is a mixed state.

questionTrap.trap: Trying to find a 'primary' driver in a mixed acid-base disorder.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In mixed cases, BOTH systems are drivers. PaCO2 is high (acidosis) and HCO3- is low (acidosis). They are working together to disrupt the pH.

mnemonic.title: Double Trouble
mnemonic.expansion: If PaCO2 and HCO3- both yell 'Acid', the result is a Disaster (mixed acidosis).
